S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) Topological Insulators in the Honeycomb Lattice

Grémaud MajuLab, CNRS-UNS-NUS-NTU International Joint Research Unit, UMI 3654, Singapore Centre for Quantum Technologies, National University of Singapore, 3 Science Drive 2, 117543 Singapore Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, National University of Singapore, 2 Science Drive 3, 117551 Singapore Laboratoire Kastler-Brossel, Ecole Normale Supérieure CNRS, UPMC; 4 Place Jussieu, F-75005 Paris, France
Abstract

We investigate realizations of topological insulators with spin-1 bosons loaded in a honeycomb optical lattice and subjected to a S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) spin-orbit coupling - a situation which can be realized experimentally using cold atomic gases. In this paper, we focus on the topological properties of the single-particle band structure, namely Chern numbers (lattice with periodic boundary conditions) and edge states (lattice with strip geometry). While S​U​(2)𝑆𝑈2SU(2) spin-orbit couplings always lead to time-reversal symmetric Hubbard models, and thereby to topologically trivial band structures, suitable S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) spin-orbit couplings can break time reversal symmetry and lead to topologically non-trivial bulk band structures and to edge states in the strip geometry. In addition, we show that one can trigger a series of topological transitions (i.e. integer changes of the Chern numbers) that are specific to the geometry of the honeycomb lattice by varying a single parameter in the Hamiltonian.

I Introduction

Over the last few years, the continuous progress in the degree of control, tunability and flexibility of ultracold atomic gases experiments Lewenstein07 ; Blochreview08 ; Ketterle2 has opened the lab door to a whole class of model Hamiltonians, as witnessed for example by the recent implementation of artificial gauge fields Spielman09a ; Spielman09b ; Spielman11 ; Zhang12 ; Zwierlein12 ; Windpassinger12 ; Spielman12 . Some of these model Hamiltonians are directly inherited from condensed matter physics, for instance the integer and fractional quantum Hall effects FCI13 ; FCIPRL1 ; FCIPRL2 . More saliently, physicists have further proposed new theoretical ideas and physical situations, such as topological phases Mottonen09 ; Bercioux11 ; Hueda12 ; YuXin15 ; Goldman2016 ; Zhai2015 , non-Abelian particles Burrello10 or mixed dimensional systems Nishida_2008 ; Nishida_2010 ; Lamporesi_2010 ; Huang_2013 ; Iskin_2010 , that could be tested in the lab. In particular, experiments involving spinors, either made of bosons or fermions in different Zeeman sub-levels, are now able to implement and study non-Abelian gauge fields Goldman2016 ; Livi2016 ; Gross2017 ; Sugawa2016 ; Ray2014 . In these systems, the kinetic energy term in the Hamiltonian allows for a modification of the internal degrees of freedom as the particle propagates Dalibard11 ; Goldman2013 , leading to a rich class of non trivial physical phenomena, especially with interactions. In two-dimensional lattices, and in particular when spin-orbit coupling is present, the corresponding non-Abelian gauge fields induce non-diagonal hopping matrices in the tight-binding Hubbard Hamiltonian that mix and flip the spin degrees of freedom Dalibard11 ; Goldman2013 . 2-component bosonic and fermionic gases (in the bulk or in a lattice) have been the subject of many recent analytical and numerical studies Lewenstein09 ; Cole_2012 ; Cai12 ; Galitski12 ; Hofstetter12 ; Fujimoto09 ; Goldman12 ; Jiri2014 ; Shenoy11 ; Sademelo12 ; Lewenstein10 ; Iskin11 ; Iskin12 ; Iskin13 ; Riedl13 .

In marked contrast, 3-component bosonic or fermionic gases subjected to a S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) gauge field have been much less studied: the experimental realization is more complicated Dalibard11 ; YuXin2014 ; Kosior2014 and their theoretical studies are more involved, the gauge field group being much larger Barnett2012 ; Mandal2016 ; Han2016 ; Grass2014 ; Go2013 . On the other hand, tight-binding models with a S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) spin-orbit coupling can break time reversal symmetry and lead to topological insulators: the bulk band structure is topologically non trivial (non-zero Chern numbers) and edge states develop for a strip geometry Barnett2012 . Such a situation cannot occur in any kind of S​U​(2)𝑆𝑈2SU(2) models as we will explain later. In addition, since S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) has a more complex group structure than S​U​(2)𝑆𝑈2SU(2), one expects a larger variety of spin textures for interacting particles. These spin textures are associated to different homotopy groups and appear both in the ground state and in the excitations above the ground state Hueda12 ; Ezawa_book ; Mandal2016 ; Han2016 ; Grass2014 ; Go2013 .

Our paper consists of three main parts. In Section II, we give some general properties of S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) Hubbard models and describe the S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) tight-binding model on the honeycomb lattice that we consider. We analyze its time-reversal properties. In Section III we study the topological properties of the band structure obtained for a lattice with periodic boundary conditions and compute the corresponding Chern numbers Resta2000 ; Paly2016 ; Niu2010 ; Houches2014 . Next we study the edge states that are expected in the lattice strip geometry, as inferred from the bulk-edge correspondence Hatsugai1993a ; Hatsugai1993b ; Hatsugai1997 ; Kane2005 ; Kane2010 . In Section IV, we show how to trigger a series of topological transitions in the band structure of our S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) model (i.e. integer changes in the Chern numbers) by varying a single parameter in the Hamiltonian. The variety of such topological transitions is richer on the honeycomb lattice than on the square lattice. In Section V, we summarize our results and conclude with some perspectives.

II S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) tight-binding models and time-reversal symmetry

II.1 Some general properties

The general tight-binding Hubbard Hamiltonian for non-interacting particles with spin s𝑠s on a two-dimensional lattice has the following form

H^=∑⟨i,j⟩𝝍^i†​Ti​j​𝝍^j,^𝐻subscript𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝝍𝑖†subscript𝑇𝑖𝑗subscript^𝝍𝑗\displaystyle\hat{H}=\sum_{\langle i,j\rangle}\hat{\bm{\psi}}_{i}^{\dagger}T_{ij}\hat{\bm{\psi}}_{j}, (1)

where the sum is carried over all nearest-neighbour lattice site pairs ⟨i,j⟩𝑖𝑗\langle i,j\rangle and where 𝝍^i†=(ψ^i,s†,…,ψ^i,−s†)superscriptsubscript^𝝍𝑖†superscriptsubscript^𝜓𝑖𝑠†…superscriptsubscript^𝜓𝑖𝑠†{\hat{\bm{\psi}}_{i}^{\dagger}=\left(\hat{\psi}_{i,s}^{\dagger},\ldots,\hat{\psi}_{i,-s}^{\dagger}\right)} is the (2​s+1)2𝑠1(2s+1)-component row-spinor built at each lattice site i𝑖i on the creation operators ψ^i,σ†subscriptsuperscript^𝜓†𝑖𝜎\hat{\psi}^{\dagger}_{i,\sigma} for each spin component σ𝜎\sigma (|σ|≤s𝜎𝑠|\sigma|\leq s). The (2​s+1)×(2​s+1)2𝑠12𝑠1(2s+1)\times(2s+1) hopping matrix Ti​jsubscript𝑇𝑖𝑗T_{ij} is connecting the different spin components at site j𝑗j to the different spin components at site i𝑖i. Since the Hamiltonian H^^𝐻\hat{H} is Hermitian, one has Tj​i=Ti​j†subscript𝑇𝑗𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑇†𝑖𝑗T_{ji}=T^{\dagger}_{ij}. S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) Hubbard models (N=2​s+1𝑁2𝑠1N=2s+1) are obtained with Ti​j=−ti​j​Ui​jsubscript𝑇𝑖𝑗subscript𝑡𝑖𝑗subscript𝑈𝑖𝑗T_{ij}=-t_{ij}U_{ij} where ti​jsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑗t_{ij} are real positive numbers and where the matrices Ui​j∈S​U​(N)subscript𝑈𝑖𝑗𝑆𝑈𝑁U_{ij}\in SU(N) describe the unitary transformation of the spin states between sites j𝑗j and i𝑖i. Using the exponentiation map, one often writes Ui​j=exp⁡(i​Ai​j)subscript𝑈𝑖𝑗isubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗U_{ij}=\exp{(\mathrm{i}A_{ij})} where Ai​jsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗A_{ij} are N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N traceless Hermitian matrices representing the gauge field acting on the system. The matrices Ai​jsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗A_{ij} live in the Lie algebra spanned by the generators of S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) GilmoreBook . Since Tj​i=Ti​j†subscript𝑇𝑗𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑇†𝑖𝑗T_{ji}=T^{\dagger}_{ij}, we have tj​i=ti​jsubscript𝑡𝑗𝑖subscript𝑡𝑖𝑗t_{ji}=t_{ij} and Uj​i=Ui​j†subscript𝑈𝑗𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑈†𝑖𝑗U_{ji}=U^{\dagger}_{ij}, which implies Aj​i=−Ai​jsubscript𝐴𝑗𝑖subscript𝐴𝑖𝑗A_{ji}=-A_{ij}. Non-Abelian S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) models are obtained when the matrices Ui​jsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑗U_{ij} do not commute, i.e. when the matrices Ai​jsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗A_{ij} do not commute, meaning that a non-Abelian gauge field is acting on the system.

When the system is invariant under a certain discrete translation group 𝒯𝐫subscript𝒯𝐫\mathcal{T}_{{\bf r}}, the spectrum of the Hamiltonian H^^𝐻\hat{H} exhibits a band structure. Note that 𝒯𝐫subscript𝒯𝐫\mathcal{T}_{{\bf r}} can differ from the Bravais translation group of the underlying lattice itself (this is the case, for example, in the presence of an external magnetic field with rational flux per plaquette). Each band n𝑛n is described by its eigenvalues ϵn​(𝐤)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝐤\epsilon_{n}(\mathbf{k}) and eigenvectors |n,𝐤⟩ket𝑛𝐤|n,\mathbf{k}\rangle for all Bloch wavevectors 𝐤𝐤\mathbf{k} in the first Brillouin zone B​Z𝐵𝑍BZ defined by the translation group 𝒯𝐫subscript𝒯𝐫\mathcal{T}_{{\bf r}}. For an isolated band, one can define the first Chern number as Niu2010 ; Houches2014

Cn=subscript𝐶𝑛absent\displaystyle C_{n}= 12​π​∫B​Zd2​𝐤​Ωn​(𝐤),12𝜋subscript𝐵𝑍superscriptd2𝐤subscriptΩ𝑛𝐤\displaystyle\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{BZ}\mathrm{d}^{2}\mathbf{k}\ \Omega_{n}(\mathbf{k}), (2)

where Ωn​(𝐤)subscriptΩ𝑛𝐤\Omega_{n}(\mathbf{k}) is the Berry curvature of the n𝑛nth band

Ωn​(𝐤)=(∇𝐤×i​⟨n,𝐤|∇𝐤|n,𝐤⟩⏟𝐀𝐧​(𝐤))⋅𝐞z,subscriptΩ𝑛𝐤⋅subscript∇𝐤subscript⏟𝑖quantum-operator-product𝑛𝐤subscript∇𝐤𝑛𝐤subscript𝐀𝐧𝐤subscript𝐞𝑧\displaystyle\Omega_{n}(\mathbf{k})=\left(\nabla_{\mathbf{k}}\times\underbrace{i\langle n,\mathbf{k}|\nabla_{\mathbf{k}}|n,\mathbf{k}\rangle}_{\mathbf{A_{n}}(\mathbf{k})}\ \right)\cdot\mathbf{e}_{z}, (3)

and 𝐀nsubscript𝐀𝑛\mathbf{A}_{n} is the Berry connection of the n𝑛nth band Niu2010 . Being an integer, the Chern number can only change when two bands touch, that is, when a gap closes. Chern numbers of a given tight-binding Hamiltonian satisfy a ”zero-sum rule”: they all add up to zero. For inversion-symmetric systems (resp. for time-reversal invariant systems), it is well known that the Berry curvature is even (resp. odd) in the B​Z𝐵𝑍BZ:

Ωn(𝐤)={+Ωn​(−𝐤)​inversion​symmetry−Ωn​(−𝐤)​time​reversal​symmetry.\displaystyle\Omega_{n}(\mathbf{k})=\left\{\begin{matrix}+\Omega_{n}(-\mathbf{k})\ \mathrm{inversion\ symmetry}\phantom{blah}\\ -\Omega_{n}(-\mathbf{k})\ \mathrm{time\ reversal\ symmetry}\end{matrix}\right..

These two properties show that: (i) the Berry curvature itself identically vanishes if H^^𝐻\hat{H} is invariant under both space inversion and time reversal; (ii) Chern numbers of time-reversal invariant Hamiltonians are necessarily vanishing. Therefore, only systems that break time reversal symmetry can have non-trivial topological properties, i.e. non-vanishing Chern numbers. In the present situation, the topological properties of a tight-binding Hamiltonian H^^𝐻\hat{H}, see Eq. (1), depend crucially on the behavior of the different Ti​jsubscript𝑇𝑖𝑗T_{ij} under time reversal.

At the single particle level, and up to an inessential overall phase factor, the (anti-unitary) time reversal operator is defined as Θ=e−i​πℏ​Jy​KΘsuperscript𝑒i𝜋Planck-constant-over-2-pisubscript𝐽𝑦𝐾{\Theta=e^{-\frac{\mathrm{i}\pi}{\hbar}J_{y}}K}, where Jysubscript𝐽𝑦J_{y} is the projection of the spin operator 𝐉𝐉{\bf J} of the particle on the y𝑦y direction and where K𝐾K is the complex conjugation operator. One has Θ2=𝟙superscriptΘ2𝟙\Theta^{2}=\openone for integer spins and Θ2=−𝟙superscriptΘ2𝟙\Theta^{2}=-\openone for half-integer spins Sakurai1986 . Under time reversal a S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) Hamiltonian becomes Bernevig2013

Θ​H^​Θ−1=−∑⟨i,j⟩ti​j​𝝍^i†​e−i​Θ​Ai​j​Θ−1​𝝍^jΘ^𝐻superscriptΘ1subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝑡𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript^𝝍𝑖†superscript𝑒iΘsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗superscriptΘ1subscript^𝝍𝑗\displaystyle\Theta\hat{H}\Theta^{-1}=-\sum_{\langle i,j\rangle}t_{ij}\hat{\bm{\psi}}_{i}^{\dagger}e^{-\mathrm{i}\Theta A_{ij}\Theta^{-1}}\hat{\bm{\psi}}_{j}

and time reversal Θ​H^​Θ−1=H^Θ^𝐻superscriptΘ1^𝐻\Theta\hat{H}\Theta^{-1}=\hat{H} is automatically guaranteed when the matrices Ai​jsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗A_{ij} are all odd under time reversal. In this case, the corresponding S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) Hubbard model is topologically trivial.

This is the situation for spin-1212\frac{1}{2} systems, where all the generators of SU(2) (Pauli-matrices) are odd under time reversal symmetry. In this case Θ=−i​σy​KΘisubscript𝜎𝑦𝐾\Theta=-\mathrm{i}\sigma_{y}K where σysubscript𝜎𝑦\sigma_{y} is the projection of the Pauli spin operator 𝝈𝝈\boldsymbol{\sigma} along axis y𝑦y. As a result, all non-interacting S​U​(2)𝑆𝑈2SU(2) Hubbard models are topologically trivial. Indeed, for S​U​(2)𝑆𝑈2SU(2) systems, Ai​j=𝜶i​j⋅𝝈subscript𝐴𝑖𝑗⋅subscript𝜶𝑖𝑗𝝈A_{ij}=\bm{\alpha}_{ij}\cdot\boldsymbol{\sigma} where 𝜶i​jsubscript𝜶𝑖𝑗\bm{\alpha}_{ij} are real vectors and Ai​jsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗A_{ij} is always odd under time reversal since Θ​𝝈​Θ−1=−𝝈Θ𝝈superscriptΘ1𝝈\Theta\boldsymbol{\sigma}\Theta^{-1}=-\boldsymbol{\sigma}.

On the contrary, for N≥3𝑁3N\geq 3, that is for spins s≥1𝑠1s\geq 1, the even sector of the Lie algebra S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N), made by the operators 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O} that fulfill Θ​𝒪​Θ−1=𝒪Θ𝒪superscriptΘ1𝒪\Theta\mathcal{O}\Theta^{-1}=\mathcal{O}, is not empty. Thus, by conveniently choosing Ai​jsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗A_{ij} in the even sector, one can break time reversal invariance and have topologically non-trivial S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) Hamiltonians. In this paper we will consider such a system for spin-111 particles. In this case, the time reversal operator is Θ=J​KΘ𝐽𝐾\Theta=JK with:

J=(0010−10100).𝐽matrix001010100\displaystyle J=\left(\begin{matrix}0&0&1\\ 0&-1&0\\ 1&0&0\end{matrix}\right). (4)

Using the generators of the S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) group, one can write Ai​j=𝜶i​j⋅𝝀subscript𝐴𝑖𝑗⋅subscript𝜶𝑖𝑗𝝀A_{ij}=\bm{\alpha}_{ij}\cdot\boldsymbol{\lambda}, where 𝜶i​jsubscript𝜶𝑖𝑗\bm{\alpha}_{ij} is a 888-component real vector and 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda} the Gell-Mann vector made of the 888 Gell-Mann matrices λasubscript𝜆𝑎\lambda_{a} (see Appendix A). From the transformation properties of the Gell-Mann matrices under time reversal, one finds that the odd sector of the Lie algebra is spanned by (λ1+λ6)subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆6(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{6}), (λ2+λ7)subscript𝜆2subscript𝜆7(\lambda_{2}+\lambda_{7}) and (λ3+3​λ8)subscript𝜆33subscript𝜆8(\lambda_{3}+\sqrt{3}\lambda_{8}), while the even sector is spanned by λ4subscript𝜆4\lambda_{4}, λ5subscript𝜆5\lambda_{5}, (λ1−λ6)subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆6(\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{6}), (λ2−λ7)subscript𝜆2subscript𝜆7(\lambda_{2}-\lambda_{7}) and (λ8−3​λ3)subscript𝜆83subscript𝜆3(\lambda_{8}-\sqrt{3}\lambda_{3}). Thus, by choosing suitable components of 𝜶i​jsubscript𝜶𝑖𝑗\bm{\alpha}_{ij} in the even sector, one can produce gauge fields Ai​jsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗A_{ij} breaking time reversal symmetry and leading to topologically non trivial S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) Hubbard models, that is to Hamiltonians with a band structure having non-trivial Chern numbers Barnett2012 . Note however that, while the time reversal invariance properties of the system can be directly and safely inferred from the matrices Ui​jsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑗U_{ij}, it is a bit more subtle when using the exponential map. Indeed one could have Ai​jsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗A_{ij} in the even sector and still preserve time reversal invariance provided that exp⁡(2​i​Ai​j)=𝟙2isubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗𝟙\exp(2\mathrm{i}A_{ij})=\openone. Ui​j=exp⁡(i​Ai​j)=15​(−12+2​i−4​i2−2​i−3−2−2​i4​i−2+2​i−1),subscript𝑈𝑖𝑗isubscript𝐴𝑖𝑗15122i4i22i322i4i22i1U_{ij}=\exp(\mathrm{i}A_{ij})=\frac{1}{5}\left(\begin{array}[]{ccc}-1&2+2\mathrm{i}&-4\mathrm{i}\\ 2-2\mathrm{i}&-3&-2-2\mathrm{i}\\ 4\mathrm{i}&-2+2\mathrm{i}&-1\end{array}\right), (5)

and one has Θ​Ui​j​Θ−1=Ui​jΘsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑗superscriptΘ1subscript𝑈𝑖𝑗\Theta U_{ij}\Theta^{-1}=U_{ij}.

In Appendix B, we give convenient parametrizations of unitary U​(3)𝑈3U(3) matrices which are even or odd under time reversal.

II.2 Non-Abelian S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) model on the honeycomb lattice

In the following, we investigate a S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) topological insulator consisting of non-interacting spin-111 bosonic particles moving on a honeycomb lattice. Our system is similar to the one studied in Ref. Barnett2012 on the square lattice. The honeycomb lattice is a triangular Bravais lattice obtained by repeated translations 𝐑​(n1,n2)=n1​𝐚1+n2​𝐚2𝐑subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛1subscript𝐚1subscript𝑛2subscript𝐚2\mathbf{R}(n_{1},n_{2})=n_{1}\mathbf{a}_{1}+n_{2}\mathbf{a}_{2} (n1subscript𝑛1n_{1} and n2subscript𝑛2n_{2} integers) of a unit cell containing two inequivalent sites denoted by A𝐴A and B𝐵B, see Fig. 1. Of importance for the following are the link vectors 𝜹1subscript𝜹1\bm{\delta}_{1}, 𝜹2subscript𝜹2\bm{\delta}_{2} and 𝜹3subscript𝜹3\bm{\delta}_{3} connecting any site A𝐴A to its 3 nearest-neighbor sites B𝐵B. They satisfy 𝜹1−𝜹2=𝐚1subscript𝜹1subscript𝜹2subscript𝐚1\bm{\delta}_{1}-\bm{\delta}_{2}=\mathbf{a}_{1}, 𝜹1−𝜹3=𝐚2subscript𝜹1subscript𝜹3subscript𝐚2\bm{\delta}_{1}-\bm{\delta}_{3}=\mathbf{a}_{2} and 𝜹1+𝜹2+𝜹3=0subscript𝜹1subscript𝜹2subscript𝜹30\bm{\delta}_{1}+\bm{\delta}_{2}+\bm{\delta}_{3}=0, see Fig. 1. The S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) matrices 𝒟=exp⁡(−2​π​i3​S^z)𝒟2𝜋i3subscript^𝑆𝑧\mathcal{D}=\exp{(-\frac{2\pi\mathrm{i}}{3}\hat{S}_{z})} and 𝒰=exp⁡[−2​π​i3​3​(λ2−λ5+λ7)]𝒰2𝜋i33subscript𝜆2subscript𝜆5subscript𝜆7\mathcal{U}=\exp{\left[-\frac{2\pi\mathrm{i}}{3\sqrt{3}}\left(\lambda_{2}-\lambda_{5}+\lambda_{7}\right)\right]} read

𝒟=(j∗0001000j)𝒰=(001100010)formulae-sequence𝒟matrixsuperscript𝑗0001000𝑗𝒰matrix001100010\displaystyle\mathcal{D}=\left(\begin{matrix}j^{*}&0&0\\ 0&1&0\\ 0&0&j\end{matrix}\right)\quad\quad\mathcal{U}=\left(\begin{matrix}0&0&1\\ 1&0&0\\ 0&1&0\end{matrix}\right) (6)

where j=exp⁡(2​i​π/3)𝑗2i𝜋3j=\exp(2\mathrm{i}\pi/3). From these expressions, one can check that T3subscript𝑇3T_{3} is breaking time reversal symmetry, which gives rise to a band structure with non-vanishing Chern number, see below Sec III. While spin states are unaffected when particles hop along link vectors 𝜹1subscript𝜹1\bm{\delta}_{1}, they acquire spin-state dependent phases when particles hop along link vectors 𝜹2subscript𝜹2\bm{\delta}_{2} and they undergo a circular permutation 1→0→−1→1→10→1→11\to 0\to-1\to 1 when particles hop along the link vectors 𝜹3subscript𝜹3\bm{\delta}_{3}. Note that, since these matrices fulfill 𝒟3=𝒰3=𝟙superscript𝒟3superscript𝒰3𝟙\mathcal{D}^{3}=\mathcal{U}^{3}=\openone, a spin state is mapped back to itself after three consecutive hoppings along a given link vector 𝜹2subscript𝜹2\bm{\delta}_{2} or 𝜹3subscript𝜹3\bm{\delta}_{3}. On the contrary, since 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} do not commute, the present spin-orbit coupling configuration corresponds to a genuine non-Abelian S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) model on the honeycomb lattice: the corresponding gauge fields A2subscript𝐴2A_{2} and A3subscript𝐴3A_{3} defined by Ta=−t​ei​Aasubscript𝑇𝑎𝑡superscript𝑒isubscript𝐴𝑎T_{a}=-te^{\mathrm{i}A_{a}} (a=2,3𝑎23a=2,3) do not commute and, therefore, the transport of a spin state around a hexagon leads to a non trivial Wilson loop value Bermudez2010 .

III Topological properties

III.1 Infinite system - Bulk spectrum

Since the unit cell of the honeycomb lattice hosts two inequivalent sites, it is customary to distinguish the bosonic annihilation and creation operators on A𝐴A and B𝐵B sites: 𝐚^n1,n2†subscriptsuperscript^𝐚†subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2\hat{\mathbf{a}}^{\dagger}_{n_{1},n_{2}} denotes the creation operator on the site 𝐑n1,n2Asubscriptsuperscript𝐑𝐴subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2\mathbf{R}^{A}_{n_{1},n_{2}} and 𝐛^n1,n2†subscriptsuperscript^𝐛†subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\dagger}_{n_{1},n_{2}} denotes the creation operator on the site 𝐑n1,n2Bsubscriptsuperscript𝐑𝐵subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2\mathbf{R}^{B}_{n_{1},n_{2}}. Each of them is a spinor of dimension 3 accounting for the 3 spin states of the spin-1 bosonic particles considered in our model.

Being translation-invariant along the Bravais vectors 𝐚1subscript𝐚1\mathbf{a}_{1} and 𝐚2subscript𝐚2\mathbf{a}_{2}, the lattice Hamiltonian is diagonal in momentum space, H^=∑𝐤∈B​ZH^𝐤^𝐻subscript𝐤𝐵𝑍subscript^𝐻𝐤\hat{H}=\sum_{\mathbf{k}\in BZ}\hat{H}_{\mathbf{k}}, where

H^𝐤subscript^𝐻𝐤\displaystyle\hat{H}_{\mathbf{k}} =−t(𝐛^𝐤†M𝐤𝐚^𝐤+H.c.)\displaystyle=-t\,\left(\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\dagger}_{\mathbf{k}}M_{\mathbf{k}}\hat{\mathbf{a}}_{\mathbf{k}}+\mathrm{H.c.}\right) (7)
M𝐤subscript𝑀𝐤\displaystyle M_{\mathbf{k}} =ei​𝐤⋅𝜹1​𝟙+𝕖i​𝐤⋅𝜹𝟚​𝒟+𝕖i​𝐤⋅𝜹𝟛​𝒰.absentsuperscript𝑒⋅i𝐤subscript𝜹1𝟙superscript𝕖⋅i𝐤subscript𝜹2𝒟superscript𝕖⋅i𝐤subscript𝜹3𝒰\displaystyle=e^{\mathrm{i}\mathbf{k}\cdot\bm{\delta}_{1}}\,\openone+e^{\mathrm{i}\mathbf{k}\cdot\bm{\delta}_{2}}\,\mathcal{D}+e^{\mathrm{i}\mathbf{k}\cdot\bm{\delta}_{3}}\,\mathcal{U}. (8)

𝐚^𝐤subscript^𝐚𝐤\hat{\mathbf{a}}_{\mathbf{k}} (resp. 𝐛^𝐤subscript^𝐛𝐤\hat{\mathbf{b}}_{\mathbf{k}}) is the Fourier transform of 𝐚^n1,n2subscript^𝐚subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2\hat{\mathbf{a}}_{n_{1},n_{2}} (resp. 𝐛^n1,n2)\hat{\mathbf{b}}_{n_{1},n_{2}}); the Bloch wavevector 𝐤𝐤\mathbf{k} belongs to the first Brillouin zone and reads

𝐤=k1​𝐛1⏟𝐤1+k2​𝐛2⏟𝐤2,|k1,2|≤1/2,formulae-sequence𝐤subscript⏟subscript𝑘1subscript𝐛1subscript𝐤1subscript⏟subscript𝑘2subscript𝐛2subscript𝐤2subscript𝑘1212\displaystyle\mathbf{k}=\underbrace{k_{1}\mathbf{b}_{1}}_{\mathbf{k}_{1}}+\underbrace{k_{2}\mathbf{b}_{2}}_{\mathbf{k}_{2}},\ |k_{1,2}|\ \leq 1/2, (9)

where the honeycomb reciprocal lattice vectors 𝐛1subscript𝐛1\mathbf{b}_{1} and 𝐛2subscript𝐛2\mathbf{b}_{2} are defined by 𝐚i⋅𝐛j=2​π​δi​j⋅subscript𝐚𝑖subscript𝐛𝑗2𝜋subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗\mathbf{a}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{b}_{j}=2\pi\delta_{ij}.

Further defining Φ^𝐤†=(𝐚^𝐤†,𝐛^𝐤†)superscriptsubscript^Φ𝐤†subscriptsuperscript^𝐚†𝐤subscriptsuperscript^𝐛†𝐤\hat{\Phi}_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}=(\hat{\mathbf{a}}^{\dagger}_{\mathbf{k}},\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\dagger}_{\mathbf{k}}), one can recast this Hamiltonian under the form H^𝐤=Φ^𝐤†​ℋ𝐤​Φ^𝐤subscript^𝐻𝐤superscriptsubscript^Φ𝐤†subscriptℋ𝐤subscript^Φ𝐤\hat{H}_{\mathbf{k}}=\hat{\Phi}_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}}\hat{\Phi}_{\mathbf{k}} where

ℋ𝐤=−t(0M𝐤†M𝐤0.)\displaystyle\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}}=-t\left(\begin{matrix}0&M_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}\\ M_{\mathbf{k}}&0\end{matrix}.\right) (10)

Diagonalizing the Bloch Hamiltonian ℋ𝐤subscriptℋ𝐤\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}} yields 6 bands ϵ1​(𝐤)≤…≤ϵ6​(𝐤)subscriptitalic-ϵ1𝐤…subscriptitalic-ϵ6𝐤\epsilon_{1}(\mathbf{k})\leq\ldots\leq\epsilon_{6}(\mathbf{k}) where the 3 (negative) lower bands are mirror images of the 3 (positive) upper bands with respect to the zero-energy plane, see Fig. 2. This mirror symmetry originates from the bipartite nature of the honeycomb lattice and is also found in the usual band structure of graphene: eigenvalues come in opposite pairs. This is because P​ℋ𝐤​P=−ℋ𝐤𝑃subscriptℋ𝐤𝑃subscriptℋ𝐤P\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}}P=-\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}} where P𝑃P is the diagonal matrix with entries 𝟙𝟙\openone and −𝟙𝟙-\openone. Noting that

ℋ𝐤2=t2​(N𝐤†​N𝐤00N𝐤​N𝐤†),subscriptsuperscriptℋ2𝐤superscript𝑡2matrixsuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝐤†subscript𝑁𝐤00subscript𝑁𝐤superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐤†\displaystyle\mathcal{H}^{2}_{\mathbf{k}}=t^{2}\left(\begin{matrix}N_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}N_{\mathbf{k}}&0\\ 0&N_{\mathbf{k}}N_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}\end{matrix}\right), (11)

where N𝐤=exp⁡(−i​𝐤⋅𝜹1)​M𝐤subscript𝑁𝐤⋅i𝐤subscript𝜹1subscript𝑀𝐤N_{\mathbf{k}}=\exp(-\mathrm{i}\mathbf{k}\cdot\bm{\delta}_{1})\,M_{\mathbf{k}}, it is easy to show that ϵn2​(𝐤)=μa2​(𝐤)​t2subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑛𝐤subscriptsuperscript𝜇2𝑎𝐤superscript𝑡2\epsilon^{2}_{n}(\mathbf{k})=\mu^{2}_{a}(\mathbf{k})\,t^{2} (a=1,2,3𝑎123a=1,2,3) where μ32​(𝐤)≤μ22​(𝐤)≤μ12​(𝐤)superscriptsubscript𝜇32𝐤superscriptsubscript𝜇22𝐤superscriptsubscript𝜇12𝐤\mu_{3}^{2}(\mathbf{k})\leq\mu_{2}^{2}(\mathbf{k})\leq\mu_{1}^{2}(\mathbf{k}) are the eigenvalues of N𝐤†​N𝐤superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐤†subscript𝑁𝐤N_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}N_{\mathbf{k}} (and also of N𝐤​N𝐤†subscript𝑁𝐤superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐤†N_{\mathbf{k}}N_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}). We thus get the band structure ϵ1,2,3=−t​μ1,2,3subscriptitalic-ϵ123𝑡subscript𝜇123\epsilon_{1,2,3}=-t\,\mu_{1,2,3} and ϵ4,5,6=t​μ3,2,1subscriptitalic-ϵ456𝑡subscript𝜇321\epsilon_{4,5,6}=t\,\mu_{3,2,1}, highlighting the mirror symmetry of the bands with respect to the zero-energy plane.

Dirac points are found at points 𝐤∈B​Z𝐤𝐵𝑍\mathbf{k}\in BZ where two eigenvalues of N𝐤†​N𝐤superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐤†subscript𝑁𝐤N_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}N_{\mathbf{k}} coalesce Comment2 . Noting that N𝐤†=S​N−𝐤​Ssuperscriptsubscript𝑁𝐤†𝑆subscript𝑁𝐤𝑆N_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}=SN_{\mathbf{-k}}S, where S𝑆S is the anti-diagonal matrix with unit entries, we see that N𝐤†​N𝐤superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐤†subscript𝑁𝐤N_{\mathbf{k}}^{\dagger}N_{\mathbf{k}} and N−𝐤​N−𝐤†subscript𝑁𝐤superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐤†N_{\mathbf{-k}}N_{\mathbf{-k}}^{\dagger}, and thus N−𝐤†​N−𝐤superscriptsubscript𝑁𝐤†subscript𝑁𝐤N_{\mathbf{-k}}^{\dagger}N_{\mathbf{-k}}, have the same spectrum. This shows that the Dirac points must come in opposite pairs in the Brillouin zone. In contrast to the graphene band structure which exhibits only 1 pair of such Dirac points, we get 9 pairs of Dirac points here, obtained when μ3​(𝐤)=0subscript𝜇3𝐤0\mu_{3}(\mathbf{k})=0, that is between bands ϵ3​(𝐤)subscriptitalic-ϵ3𝐤\epsilon_{3}(\mathbf{k}) and ϵ4​(𝐤)subscriptitalic-ϵ4𝐤\epsilon_{4}(\mathbf{k}). The other bands remain fully isolated. Hence, just like graphene, our system is a semi-metal. We note that getting 9 pairs of Dirac points is not generic but specific to our S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) model. It arises from an additional symmetry in our Hamiltonian due to our particular choice of the hopping matrices 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} and 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. We point out that this is not because of a smaller effective Brillouin zone since our Hamiltonian, as can be seen from the expression of M𝐤subscript𝑀𝐤M_{\mathbf{k}} above, is invariant under Bravais translations only. Instead, one can show that

N𝐤+𝐛1/3=𝒰​N𝐤​𝒰†subscript𝑁𝐤subscript𝐛13𝒰subscript𝑁𝐤superscript𝒰†\displaystyle N_{\mathbf{k}+\mathbf{b}_{1}/3}=\mathcal{U}N_{\mathbf{k}}\mathcal{U}^{\dagger} (12)
N𝐤+𝐛2/3=𝒟†​N𝐤​𝒟,subscript𝑁𝐤subscript𝐛23superscript𝒟†subscript𝑁𝐤𝒟\displaystyle N_{\mathbf{k}+\mathbf{b}_{2}/3}=\mathcal{D}^{\dagger}N_{\mathbf{k}}\mathcal{D}, (13)

meaning that the matrices N𝐤+𝐛i/3subscript𝑁𝐤subscript𝐛𝑖3N_{\mathbf{k}+\mathbf{b}_{i}/3} (i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2) and N𝐤subscript𝑁𝐤N_{\mathbf{k}} are unitarily equivalent. Thus, up to a global gauge transform, the two Hamiltonians ℋ𝐤+𝐛1/3subscriptℋ𝐤subscript𝐛13\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}+\mathbf{b}_{1}/3} and ℋ𝐤subscriptℋ𝐤\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}} are identical. The same conclusion holds true for Hamiltonians ℋ𝐤+𝐛2/3subscriptℋ𝐤subscript𝐛23\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}+\mathbf{b}_{2}/3} and ℋ𝐤subscriptℋ𝐤\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}}. Going back to the direct lattice, these global gauge transforms amount to a ”rotation” of the spin degrees of freedom on each individual lattice site by the same unitary matrix. This shows that the Hamiltonians ℋ𝐤+𝐛1/3subscriptℋ𝐤subscript𝐛13\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}+\mathbf{b}_{1}/3}, ℋ𝐤+𝐛2/3subscriptℋ𝐤subscript𝐛23\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}+\mathbf{b}_{2}/3} and ℋ𝐤subscriptℋ𝐤\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}} have the same spectra. We thus infer that ϵn​(𝐤)=ϵn​(𝐤+𝐛1/3)=ϵn​(𝐤+𝐛2/3)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝐤subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝐤subscript𝐛13subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝐤subscript𝐛23\epsilon_{n}(\mathbf{k})=\epsilon_{n}(\mathbf{k}+\mathbf{b}_{1}/3)=\epsilon_{n}(\mathbf{k}+\mathbf{b}_{2}/3) for each energy band.

Note that a mass term such as Δ​(n^A−n^B)/2Δsubscript^𝑛𝐴subscript^𝑛𝐵2\Delta(\hat{n}_{A}-\hat{n}_{B})/2 does not break the mirror symmetry between positive and negative eigenvalues, nor does it break the translation invariance of the lattice Hamiltonian. But it does lift the band degeneracies. Indeed, it adds the terms Δ/2Δ2\Delta/2 and −Δ/2Δ2-\Delta/2 on the diagonal entries of ℋ𝐤subscriptℋ𝐤\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}}, Eq.(10), and the constant term Δ2/4superscriptΔ24\Delta^{2}/4 on the diagonal entries of ℋ𝐤2subscriptsuperscriptℋ2𝐤\mathcal{H}^{2}_{\mathbf{k}}, leading to ϵn​(𝐤,Δ)=±t​μa2​(𝐤)+(Δ/2​t)2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝐤Δplus-or-minus𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑎2𝐤superscriptΔ2𝑡2\epsilon_{n}(\mathbf{k},\Delta)=\pm t\,\sqrt{\mu_{a}^{2}(\mathbf{k})+(\Delta/2t)^{2}} and thus to ϵn​(𝐤,Δ)=−ϵ7−n​(𝐤,Δ)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝐤Δsubscriptitalic-ϵ7𝑛𝐤Δ\epsilon_{n}(\mathbf{k},\Delta)=-\epsilon_{7-n}(\mathbf{k},\Delta). This shows that Cn​(Δ)=C7−n​(Δ)subscript𝐶𝑛Δsubscript𝐶7𝑛ΔC_{n}(\Delta)=C_{7-n}(\Delta): the Chern numbers come in equal pairs Comment3 . Because of this symmetry, the total zero-sum rule of Chern numbers boils down to 2 separate zero-sum rules C1+C2+C3=C4+C5+C6=0subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3subscript𝐶4subscript𝐶5subscript𝐶60C_{1}+C_{2}+C_{3}=C_{4}+C_{5}+C_{6}=0.

We now turn to the numerical computation of the Chern numbers. Strictly speaking, Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n}, as given by Eq. (2), is only well-defined for an isolated band. Since the 2 middle bands ϵ3subscriptitalic-ϵ3\epsilon_{3} and ϵ4subscriptitalic-ϵ4\epsilon_{4} are touching, we add a small mass term Δ=0.1​tΔ0.1𝑡\Delta=0.1t, such that the six bands are fully isolated. Following Fukui2005 , this allows to safely compute Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n} for each band and quantify the topology of the band structure. For our S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) model, we find C1=3subscript𝐶13C_{1}=3, C2=−6subscript𝐶26C_{2}=-6 and C3=3subscript𝐶33C_{3}=3 Comments4 . These nonzero values signal non-trivial topological properties of the bulk band structure.

III.2 Finite system - Edge states

As is well known, a lattice Hamiltonian having a band structure with non-vanishing Chern numbers exhibits edge states in a strip geometry Kane2010 . We consider such a finite lattice strip for our S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) model and compute the spectrum for open boundary conditions in the 𝐚1subscript𝐚1\mathbf{a}_{1} direction (0≤n1≤N0subscript𝑛1𝑁0\leq n_{1}\leq N) and periodic boundary conditions in the 𝐚2subscript𝐚2\mathbf{a}_{2} direction (unrestricted n2subscript𝑛2n_{2}). The lattice strip we consider has left and right zig-zag boundaries. Since the Hamiltonian is still invariant under lattice translations along 𝐚2subscript𝐚2\mathbf{a}_{2}, the Bloch wavevector along 𝐛2subscript𝐛2\mathbf{b}_{2} remains a good quantum number. Therefore, we introduce the Fourier transform operators 𝐚^n1,k2subscript^𝐚subscript𝑛1subscript𝑘2\hat{\mathbf{a}}_{n_{1},k_{2}} and 𝐛^n1,k2subscript^𝐛subscript𝑛1subscript𝑘2\hat{\mathbf{b}}_{n_{1},k_{2}} along 𝐚2subscript𝐚2\mathbf{a}_{2}. The Hamiltonian, for a given Bloch wavevector k2subscript𝑘2k_{2}, now reads:

H^k2=−t​∑n1=0Nsubscript^𝐻subscript𝑘2𝑡superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑛10𝑁\displaystyle\hat{H}_{k_{2}}=-t\sum_{n_{1}=0}^{N} 𝐛^n1,k2†​(ei​𝐤2⋅𝜹1​𝟙+𝕖𝕚​𝐤𝟚⋅𝜹𝟛​𝒰)​𝐚^𝕟𝟙,𝕜𝟚subscriptsuperscript^𝐛†subscript𝑛1subscript𝑘2superscript𝑒⋅𝑖subscript𝐤2subscript𝜹1𝟙superscript𝕖⋅𝕚subscript𝐤2subscript𝜹3𝒰subscriptsuperscript^𝐚absentsubscript𝕟1subscript𝕜2\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\dagger}_{n_{1},k_{2}}(e^{i\mathbf{k}_{2}\cdot\bm{\delta}_{1}}\openone+e^{i\mathbf{k}_{2}\cdot\bm{\delta}_{3}}\mathcal{U})\,\hat{\mathbf{a}}^{\phantom{\dagger}}_{n_{1},k_{2}}
−t​∑n1=1N𝑡superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑛11𝑁\displaystyle-t\sum_{n_{1}=1}^{N} 𝐛^n1−1,k2†​ei​𝐤2⋅𝜹2​𝒟​𝐚^n1,k2+H.c.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript^𝐛†subscript𝑛11subscript𝑘2superscript𝑒⋅𝑖subscript𝐤2subscript𝜹2𝒟subscriptsuperscript^𝐚absentsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑘2Hc\displaystyle\hat{\mathbf{b}}^{\dagger}_{n_{1}-1,k_{2}}e^{i\mathbf{k}_{2}\cdot\bm{\delta}_{2}}\mathcal{D}\,\hat{\mathbf{a}}^{\phantom{\dagger}}_{n_{1},k_{2}}+\mathrm{H.c.} (14)

with |k2|≤1/2subscript𝑘212|k_{2}|\leq 1/2. By diagonalizing H^k2subscript^𝐻subscript𝑘2\hat{H}_{k_{2}}, we obtain the band spectrum shown in Fig. 3. This spectrum has to be compared to the bulk spectrum, shown in Fig. 4, that has been obtained for the same number of cells N𝑁N along 𝐚1subscript𝐚1\mathbf{a}_{1} but with periodic boundary conditions. As expected from our analysis of the bulk spectrum, we indeed find additional states in the gaps between bands with different Chern numbers, that is between the first and second bands, between the second and third bands and, by symmetry, between the fourth and fifth bands and between the fifth and sixth bands. No additional states appear between the third and the fourth band, since these two bands have equal Chern numbers.

Let us define the position xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} (i=1,…,2​N𝑖1…2𝑁i=1,\ldots,2N) of the sites along a given horizontal zig-zag chain crossing the lattice strip from left to right. We denote by Pn​(xi,k2)subscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑘2P_{n}(x_{i},k_{2}) the spatial distribution of the eigenstate with eigenvalue ϵn​(k2)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛subscript𝑘2\epsilon_{n}(k_{2}) along this chain. The color scale of Fig. 3 shows the average position dn=∑ixi​Pn​(xi,k2)subscript𝑑𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑘2d_{n}=\sum_{i}x_{i}P_{n}(x_{i},k_{2}) of the eigenstate in the strip. We see that states chosen within the bulk-like bands spread uniformly over the whole lattice strip and dnsubscript𝑑𝑛d_{n} lies at the center of the lattice strip. On the contrary, states connecting bulk-like bands with different Chern numbers are either strongly localized on the left boundary (black) or on the right boundary (green) of the lattice: these are the celebrated edge states. We also see that, in our system, edge states within a given gap are localized on one side of the strip when their group velocity is positive and on the other side of the strip when their group velocity is negative. This one-to-one correspondence between the sign of the slope of the energy dispersion relation of an edge state and its spatial localization changes from one gap to the other. This feature, particular to our system, emphasizes the chiral character expected for particle transport at the boundaries. Interestingly, one can recover the values of the Chern numbers of our bulk system from the bulk-edge correspondence  Hatsugai1993a ; Hatsugai1993b ; Hatsugai1997 . Within a given gap, one counts the number of edge state N+subscript𝑁N_{+} and N−subscript𝑁N_{-} with positive and negative group velocities that give rise to a localization on the right side of the strip. The difference (N+−N−)subscript𝑁subscript𝑁(N_{+}-N_{-}) is then equal to the sum of the Chern numbers of all the bands below the gap considered. This recipe allows to reconstruct all Chern numbers with their sign. It is easy to check that we do recover the values computed in the preceding paragraph. For instance, the absence of edge states linking the third and the fourth bands (N+=N−=0subscript𝑁subscript𝑁0N_{+}=N_{-}=0) is in agreement with the fact that the sum of the Chern numbers of the three lowest bands vanishes, N+−N−=C1+C2+C3=0subscript𝑁subscript𝑁subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶30N_{+}-N_{-}=C_{1}+C_{2}+C_{3}=0.

The probability distribution Pn​(xi,k2)∝eγ​xiproportional-tosubscript𝑃𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑘2superscript𝑒𝛾subscript𝑥𝑖P_{n}(x_{i},k_{2})\propto e^{\gamma x_{i}} of an edge state decays exponentially with xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} when it is localized at n1=0subscript𝑛10n_{1}=0 (γ<0𝛾0\gamma<0) and grows exponentially with xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} when it is localized at n1=Nsubscript𝑛1𝑁n_{1}=N (γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0). The (positive or negative) value of the characteristic scale 1/γ1𝛾1/\gamma depends both on the edge state considered and on the Bloch wavector k2subscript𝑘2k_{2}. This is emphasized in Fig. 5b where we plot γ𝛾\gamma as a function of k2subscript𝑘2k_{2} for the edge states with the dispersion relation highlighted in Fig. 5a. As one can see, the state is localized on the left side of the strip (n1=0subscript𝑛10n_{1}=0) as long as its group velocity is negative. For values of k2subscript𝑘2k_{2} roughly in the range 0.6−0.70.60.70.6-0.7, the state dives into the bulk band and becomes delocalized. The decay coefficient γ𝛾\gamma then vanishes. For larger k2subscript𝑘2k_{2} values, the group velocity becomes positive and the state is now localized on the right side of the strip (n1=Nsubscript𝑛1𝑁n_{1}=N). Finally, Fig. 5c shows the probability distribution Pnsubscript𝑃𝑛P_{n} for the different edge states shown in Fig. 5a) for a given value of k2≃0.458similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑘20.458k_{2}\simeq 0.458. Here again, one can see the correlation observed in our system between the sign of the group velocity and the localization center of the edge state.

IV Topological transitions

The Chern number of a given isolated band is an invariant integer-valued topological quantity. Its value can only change when the band comes in contact with another one. A vanishing gap can be achieved by changing parameters in the Hamiltonian, for example the strength of the spin-orbit coupling. In general, the hopping matrices along links 𝜹asubscript𝜹𝑎\bm{\delta}_{a} can be written as Ta=−t​exp⁡(i​Aa)subscript𝑇𝑎𝑡isubscript𝐴𝑎T_{a}=-t\exp{(\mathrm{i}A_{a})} (a=1,2,3𝑎123a=1,2,3). The traceless Hermitian featuring gauge field can be written as Aa=𝜶a⋅𝝀subscript𝐴𝑎⋅subscript𝜶𝑎𝝀A_{a}=\bm{\alpha}_{a}\cdot\bm{\lambda}, where 𝜶asubscript𝜶𝑎\bm{\alpha}_{a} is a real 8-component vector and 𝝀𝝀\bm{\lambda} is the 8-component vector made of the Gell-Mann matrices. We have first monitored the band structure, gaps and Chern numbers by considering various configurations of the three vectors 𝜶asubscript𝜶𝑎\bm{\alpha}_{a}. However, for all configurations that we tested, we could only recover the set of Chern numbers (3,−6,3)363(3,-6,3) already found in Section III for the 3 negative bands, or the opposite set (−3,6,−3)363(-3,6,-3). The same result was obtained by allowing for imbalanced tunneling amplitudes, that is Ta=−ta​exp⁡(i​Aa)subscript𝑇𝑎subscript𝑡𝑎isubscript𝐴𝑎T_{a}=-t_{a}\exp{(\mathrm{i}A_{a})}, and by varying the tasubscript𝑡𝑎t_{a}.

More saliently, we found other topological transitions giving rise to different sets of Chern numbers by adding a spin-dependent chemical potential term −(μA​nA+μB​nB)subscript𝜇𝐴subscript𝑛𝐴subscript𝜇𝐵subscript𝑛𝐵-(\mu_{A}n_{A}+\mu_{B}n_{B}) to the Hamiltonian. The chemical potential matrix for A𝐴A sites reads μA=−Δ/2​𝟙+δ​μ𝔸​𝕊𝕫subscript𝜇𝐴Δ2𝟙𝛿subscript𝜇𝔸subscript𝕊𝕫\mu_{A}=-\Delta/2\,\openone+\delta\mu_{A}S_{z} and μB=Δ/2​𝟙+δ​μ𝔹​𝕊𝕫subscript𝜇𝐵Δ2𝟙𝛿subscript𝜇𝔹subscript𝕊𝕫\mu_{B}=\Delta/2\,\openone+\delta\mu_{B}S_{z} for B𝐵B sites. Note that ΔΔ\Delta is the usual (spin-independent) mass term (see Section III). All in all, we found that the two following spin-dependent chemical potential configurations

  • ∙∙\bullet

    δ​μB=−δ​μA=ΔS/2𝛿subscript𝜇𝐵𝛿subscript𝜇𝐴subscriptΔ𝑆2\delta\mu_{B}=-\delta\mu_{A}=\Delta_{S}/2 (spin-dependent mass imbalance).

  • ∙∙\bullet

    δ​μB=δ​μA𝛿subscript𝜇𝐵𝛿subscript𝜇𝐴\delta\mu_{B}=\delta\mu_{A} (spin-dependent local potential).

with an additional spin-orbit coupling along 𝜹1subscript𝜹1\bm{\delta}_{1} gave rise to a larger variety of Chern numbers. We point out that, without this additional spin-orbit coupling, one can still find Chern numbers differing from ±(3,−6,3)plus-or-minus363\pm(3,-6,3), but only for some particular values of the spin-orbit couplings along 𝜹2subscript𝜹2\bm{\delta}_{2} and 𝜹3subscript𝜹3\bm{\delta}_{3}.

As an example, we consider a system with spin-dependent mass imbalance (ΔS≠0subscriptΔ𝑆0\Delta_{S}\neq 0) and non-Abelian hopping matrices T1=−t​𝒱=−t​exp⁡(i​A1)subscript𝑇1𝑡𝒱𝑡isubscript𝐴1T_{1}=-t\,\mathcal{V}=-t\exp{(\mathrm{i}A_{1})} where A1=2​π3​3​(λ1+λ4+λ6)subscript𝐴12𝜋33subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆4subscript𝜆6A_{1}=\frac{2\pi}{3\sqrt{3}}(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{4}+\lambda_{6}), T2=−t​𝒟subscript𝑇2𝑡𝒟T_{2}=-t\,\mathcal{D} and T3=−t​𝒰subscript𝑇3𝑡𝒰T_{3}=-t\,\mathcal{U}. For sake of simplicity, we also choose Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0. Fig. 6 shows the 6 Chern numbers Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n} and the different band gaps that are obtained as a function of ΔSsubscriptΔ𝑆\Delta_{S}. As one can see, we get new sets of Chern numbers now and not just ±(3,−6,3)plus-or-minus363\pm(3,-6,3), see Table 1. The vertical lines in Fig. 6 are guides to the eye that mark a gap closing between 2 adjacent bands. We see that the different gaps do not close at the same time. This emphasizes that it is only the pair of Chern numbers Cn+1subscript𝐶𝑛1C_{n+1} and Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n} of the bands involved in the gap closing gn+1,n=0subscript𝑔𝑛1𝑛0g_{n+1,n}=0 that can change. One has:

(Cn+1+Cn)after=(Cn+1+Cn)before,subscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛1subscript𝐶𝑛aftersubscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛1subscript𝐶𝑛before\displaystyle\left(C_{n+1}+C_{n}\right)_{\textrm{after}}=\left(C_{n+1}+C_{n}\right)_{\textrm{before}}, (15)

the other Chern numbers remain unaffected. We further note that changing the sign of all the mass imbalances amounts to flipping the sign of the eigenvalues of the Hamiltonian, ϵn​(𝐤,−Δ,−ΔS)=−ϵ7−n​(𝐤,Δ,ΔS)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛𝐤ΔsubscriptΔ𝑆subscriptitalic-ϵ7𝑛𝐤ΔsubscriptΔ𝑆\epsilon_{n}(\mathbf{k},-\Delta,-\Delta_{S})=-\,\epsilon_{7-n}(\mathbf{k},\Delta,\Delta_{S}). Again, this is because P​ℋ𝐤​(Δ,ΔS)​P=−ℋ𝐤​(−Δ,−ΔS)𝑃subscriptℋ𝐤ΔsubscriptΔ𝑆𝑃subscriptℋ𝐤ΔsubscriptΔ𝑆P\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}}(\Delta,\Delta_{S})P=-\mathcal{H}_{\mathbf{k}}(-\Delta,-\Delta_{S}). We therefore have the property that C7−n​(Δ,ΔS)=Cn​(−Δ,−ΔS)subscript𝐶7𝑛ΔsubscriptΔ𝑆subscript𝐶𝑛ΔsubscriptΔ𝑆C_{7-n}(\Delta,\Delta_{S})=C_{n}(-\Delta,-\Delta_{S}). This symmetry in the Chern numbers can be readily checked in Fig. 6 obtained for Δ=0Δ0\Delta=0. One also confirms that gaps have the same symmetry, gn+1,n​(ΔS)=g7−n,6−n​(−ΔS)subscript𝑔𝑛1𝑛subscriptΔ𝑆subscript𝑔7𝑛6𝑛subscriptΔ𝑆g_{n+1,n}(\Delta_{S})=g_{7-n,6-n}(-\Delta_{S}), from which one concludes that g43subscript𝑔43g_{43} is symmetric in ΔSsubscriptΔ𝑆\Delta_{S}. We also note that the gap g43subscript𝑔43g_{43} only closes at ΔS=0subscriptΔ𝑆0\Delta_{S}=0 but that this degeneracy does not modify C3subscript𝐶3C_{3} and C4subscript𝐶4C_{4}. As a consequence, the change in Chern numbers after a gap closing can only occur within the subset (C1,C2,C3)subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3(C_{1},C_{2},C_{3}) or within (C4,C5,C6)subscript𝐶4subscript𝐶5subscript𝐶6(C_{4},C_{5},C_{6}). The Chern numbers thus satisfy again the separate zero-sum rules C1+C2+C3=C4+C5+C6=0subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶3subscript𝐶4subscript𝐶5subscript𝐶60C_{1}+C_{2}+C_{3}=C_{4}+C_{5}+C_{6}=0. Finally all bands eventually reach a vanishing Chern number for large enough values of |ΔS|subscriptΔ𝑆|\Delta_{S}|, even though the Berry curvatures neither vanish nor display any particular symmetry. Fig. 7 shows a plot of the Berry curvature of the second band ϵ2​(𝐤,ΔS)subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝐤subscriptΔ𝑆\epsilon_{2}(\mathbf{k},\Delta_{S}) in the Brillouin zone obtained for ΔS=−2.6subscriptΔ𝑆2.6\Delta_{S}=-2.6 where C2=1subscript𝐶21C_{2}=1 (top plot) and for ΔS=−4subscriptΔ𝑆4\Delta_{S}=-4 where C2=0subscript𝐶20C_{2}=0 (bottom plot). In both cases, the Berry curvatures exhibit qualitatively similar structures.

As explained above, such a rich variety of Chern numbers and topological transitions have been obtained by imposing spin-dependent chemical potentials on sites A𝐴A and B𝐵B and different spin-orbit couplings along the 3 links, keeping intact, at the same time, the underlying triangular Bravais symmetry of the honeycomb lattice. We have studied the same situation on the square lattice (not shown here) but were not able to find such a rich variety of Chern numbers and topological transitions. The probable reason is that the square lattice has only 2 link vectors and thus accommodates less configurations of spin-orbit couplings. From that point of view, the S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) model on the honeycomb lattice exhibits a band structure with richer topological properties.

A similarly rich variety of topological transitions and Chern numbers is obtained by allowing for complex 𝜶asubscript𝜶𝑎\bm{\alpha}_{a} in the gauge fields Aa=𝜶a⋅𝝀subscript𝐴𝑎⋅subscript𝜶𝑎𝝀A_{a}=\bm{\alpha}_{a}\cdot\bm{\lambda}. However, this situation, even if experimentally feasible, does not correspond to a pure S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) gauge potential anymore.

We emphasize that the bulk bands remain well isolated for a large variety of gauge fields Aasubscript𝐴𝑎A_{a} and for many values of the the spin-dependent mass imbalance ΔSsubscriptΔ𝑆\Delta_{S}. However, even though the bands do not touch at any point in the Brillouin zone, they can still overlap on the energy axis, which means that there is no charge gap separating them. This situation is depicted in Fig. 8 for Δ=ΔS=0ΔsubscriptΔ𝑆0\Delta=\Delta_{S}=0, T1=−t​𝒰subscript𝑇1𝑡𝒰T_{1}=-t\,\mathcal{U}, T2=−t​𝒟subscript𝑇2𝑡𝒟T_{2}=-t\,\mathcal{D} and T3=−t​𝒱subscript𝑇3𝑡𝒱T_{3}=-t\,\mathcal{V}. But, since the Chern numbers are still well defined, topological edge states linking the different bands still appear in the strip lattice configuration. On the other hand, the absence of charge gaps prevents the system from behaving like a Chern insulator and no Hall plateaus are then expected in transverse conductance measurements.

V Conclusion

We have studied the topological properties of a non-interacting Hubbard model on the honeycomb lattice with S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) spin-orbit couplings. We have emphasized that, in marked contrast with lattice S​U​(2)𝑆𝑈2SU(2) models which are always topologically trivial, these S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) models can break time reversal invariance. As a consequence, their bulk band structure becomes topologically non trivial: bulk bands have non-zero Chern numbers and chiral edge states develop in a lattice strip configuration with open boundary conditions. We have also shown that S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) models on the honeycomb lattice allow for a larger variety of topological transitions than on the square lattice Barnett2012 because of a higher lattice coordination number.

A natural extension of the present work is to include interactions in our model and understand their impact on the topological properties of the system, in particular the emergence of non-trivial spin textures breaking the translation symmetry of the lattice Cole_2012 ; Hofstetter12 ; Grass2014 ; Mandal2016 . Because S​U​(3)𝑆𝑈3SU(3) is a larger gauge group than S​U​(2)𝑆𝑈2SU(2), we expect a much larger variety of topological properties for these spin textures Hueda12 ; Ezawa_book .

This results holds true for any unitary N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N matrix which is odd under time reversal provided N𝑁N is odd. Indeed (Det​Uo​d​d)∗=Det​(−Uo​d​d)=(−1)N​Det​Uo​d​dsuperscriptDetsubscript𝑈𝑜𝑑𝑑Detsubscript𝑈𝑜𝑑𝑑superscript1𝑁Detsubscript𝑈𝑜𝑑𝑑(\textrm{Det}\,U_{odd})^{*}=\textrm{Det}(-U_{odd})=(-1)^{N}\textrm{Det}\,U_{odd} shows that Det​Uo​d​dDetsubscript𝑈𝑜𝑑𝑑\textrm{Det}\,U_{odd} is purely imaginary when N𝑁N is odd. Thus Uo​d​dsubscript𝑈𝑜𝑑𝑑U_{odd} cannot belong to S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) and S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) matrices breaking time reversal invariance cannot be odd when N𝑁N is odd. When N𝑁N is even, Uo​d​dsubscript𝑈𝑜𝑑𝑑U_{odd} is unimodular. This means that it is possible to have S​U​(N)𝑆𝑈𝑁SU(N) matrices which are odd under time reversal when N𝑁N is even, with the notable exception of N=2𝑁2N=2, as shown in the paper.
